natural problem: Navin from Mauritius, Luka from Croatia, and Ian from Botswana are chatting in the lobby of a youth hostel discussing their part-time jobs. They learn that Navin makes 160 rupee per hour, Luka makes 25 kuna per hour, and Ian makes 34 pula per hour. If one US dollar is equivalent to 32.35 Mauritius rupee, 5.18 Croatian kuna, and 6.95 Botswana pula, who would earn the most after working an eight-hour day?
natural solution: The easiest way to solve this problem is to convert the wages to US dollars and to ignore the eight-hour day. In one hour Navin makes $160\text{ rupee} \times \frac{1\text{ USD}}{32.35\text{ rupee}}\approx 4.95\; \text{USD}$.

Luka makes $25 \text{ kuna} \times \frac{1\text{ USD}}{5.18 \text{ kuna}}\approx 4.83 \text{ USD}$. Ian makes $34\text{ pula} \times\frac{1\text{ USD}}{6.95 \text{ pula}}\approx 4.89 \text{ USD}$. Comparing these numbers, we see that $\boxed{\text{Navin}}$ has the highest per-hour wages, and therefore would earn the most in eight hours.

a_0.formal problem:
definition Navin_daily :: "real" where "Navin_daily = Navin_hourly * hours / rate_rupee"
definition Luka_daily :: "real" where "Luka_daily = Luka_hourly * hours / rate_kuna"
definition Ian_daily :: "real" where "Ian_daily = Ian_hourly * hours / rate_pula"

theorem
shows  "Navin_daily > Luka_daily \<and> Navin_daily > Ian_daily"
end
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Navin from Mauritius, Luka from Croatia, and Ian from Botswana are chatting in the lobby of a youth hostel discussing their part-time jobs. They learn that Navin makes 160 rupee per hour, Luka makes 25 kuna per hour, and Ian makes 34 pula per hour. If one US dollar is equivalent to 32.35 Mauritius rupee, 5.18 Croatian kuna, and 6.95 Botswana pula, who would earn the most after working an eight-hour day? The final Answer is \text{Navin}
 ### Proof
 The easiest way to solve this problem is to convert the wages to US dollars and to ignore the eight-hour day. In one hour Navin makes $160\text{ rupee} \times \frac{1\text{ USD}}{32.35\text{ rupee}}\approx 4.95\; \text{USD}$.
 Luka makes $25 \text{ kuna} \times \frac{1\text{ USD}}{5.18 \text{ kuna}}\approx 4.83 \text{ USD}$. Ian makes $34\text{ pula} \times\frac{1\text{ USD}}{6.95 \text{ pula}}\approx 4.89 \text{ USD}$. Comparing these numbers, we see that $\boxed{\text{Navin}}$ has the highest per-hour wages, and therefore would earn the most in eight hours.
 *)



definition Navin_daily :: "real" where "Navin_daily = Navin_hourly * hours / rate_rupee"
definition Luka_daily :: "real" where "Luka_daily = Luka_hourly * hours / rate_kuna"
definition Ian_daily :: "real" where "Ian_daily = Ian_hourly * hours / rate_pula"

theorem
shows  "Navin_daily > Luka_daily \<and> Navin_daily > Ian_daily"
end
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Navin, Luka, and Ian are all paid hourly and work the same number of hours each day. However, they are paid in different currencies: Navin in rupees, Luka in kuna, and Ian in pula. The daily earnings for each of them are calculated by multiplying their hourly wage by the number of hours they work and then dividing by the exchange rate for their respective currencies. Prove that Navin earns more each day than both Luka and Ian.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes navin_hourly luka_hourly ian_hourly :: real
and rupee_dollar kuna_dollar pula_dollar :: real
and navin_daily luka_daily ian_daily :: real
assumes h0 : "navin_hourly = 160 / rupee_dollar"
and h1 : "luka_hourly = 25 / kuna_dollar"
and h2 : "ian_hourly = 34 / pula_dollar"
and h3 : "navin_daily = 8 * navin_hourly"
and h4 : "luka_daily = 8 * luka_hourly"
and h5 : "ian_daily = 8 * ian_hourly"
and h6 : "rupee_dollar = 32.35"
and h7 : "kuna_dollar = 5.18"
and h8 : "pula_dollar = 6.95"
shows  "max (max navin_daily luka_daily) ian_daily = navin_daily"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Navin from Mauritius, Luka from Croatia, and Ian from Botswana are chatting in the lobby of a youth hostel discussing their part-time jobs. They learn that Navin makes 160 rupee per hour, Luka makes 25 kuna per hour, and Ian makes 34 pula per hour. If one US dollar is equivalent to 32.35 Mauritius rupee, 5.18 Croatian kuna, and 6.95 Botswana pula, who would earn the most after working an eight-hour day? The final Answer is \text{Navin}
 ### Proof
 The easiest way to solve this problem is to convert the wages to US dollars and to ignore the eight-hour day. In one hour Navin makes $160\text{ rupee} \times \frac{1\text{ USD}}{32.35\text{ rupee}}\approx 4.95\; \text{USD}$.
 Luka makes $25 \text{ kuna} \times \frac{1\text{ USD}}{5.18 \text{ kuna}}\approx 4.83 \text{ USD}$. Ian makes $34\text{ pula} \times\frac{1\text{ USD}}{6.95 \text{ pula}}\approx 4.89 \text{ USD}$. Comparing these numbers, we see that $\boxed{\text{Navin}}$ has the highest per-hour wages, and therefore would earn the most in eight hours.
 *)

theorem
fixes navin_hourly luka_hourly ian_hourly :: real
and rupee_dollar kuna_dollar pula_dollar :: real
and navin_daily luka_daily ian_daily :: real
assumes h0 : "navin_hourly = 160 / rupee_dollar"
and h1 : "luka_hourly = 25 / kuna_dollar"
and h2 : "ian_hourly = 34 / pula_dollar"
and h3 : "navin_daily = 8 * navin_hourly"
and h4 : "luka_daily = 8 * luka_hourly"
and h5 : "ian_daily = 8 * ian_hourly"
and h6 : "rupee_dollar = 32.35"
and h7 : "kuna_dollar = 5.18"
and h8 : "pula_dollar = 6.95"
shows  "max (max navin_daily luka_daily) ian_daily = navin_daily"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Navin earns 160 Rupees per hour, Luka earns 25 Kuna per hour, and Ian earns 34 Pula per hour. They each work 8 hours a day. Given that 1 Dollar is equivalent to 32.35 Rupees, 5.18 Kuna, and 6.95 Pula, who has the highest daily earnings when converted to Dollars? The final answer is Navin.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes navin_hourly :: real
and luka_hourly :: real
and ian_hourly :: real
and navin_daily :: real
and luka_daily :: real
and ian_daily :: real
and usd_to_rupee :: real
and usd_to_kuna :: real
and usd_to_pula :: real
assumes h0 : "navin_hourly = 160 / usd_to_rupee"
and h1 : "luka_hourly = 25 / usd_to_kuna"
and h2 : "ian_hourly = 34 / usd_to_pula"
and h3 : "navin_daily = 8 * navin_hourly"
and h4 : "luka_daily = 8 * luka_hourly"
and h5 : "ian_daily = 8 * ian_hourly"
shows  "navin_daily > luka_daily \<and> navin_daily > ian_daily"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Navin from Mauritius, Luka from Croatia, and Ian from Botswana are chatting in the lobby of a youth hostel discussing their part-time jobs. They learn that Navin makes 160 rupee per hour, Luka makes 25 kuna per hour, and Ian makes 34 pula per hour. If one US dollar is equivalent to 32.35 Mauritius rupee, 5.18 Croatian kuna, and 6.95 Botswana pula, who would earn the most after working an eight-hour day? The final Answer is \text{Navin}
 ### Proof
 The easiest way to solve this problem is to convert the wages to US dollars and to ignore the eight-hour day. In one hour Navin makes $160\text{ rupee} \times \frac{1\text{ USD}}{32.35\text{ rupee}}\approx 4.95\; \text{USD}$.
 Luka makes $25 \text{ kuna} \times \frac{1\text{ USD}}{5.18 \text{ kuna}}\approx 4.83 \text{ USD}$. Ian makes $34\text{ pula} \times\frac{1\text{ USD}}{6.95 \text{ pula}}\approx 4.89 \text{ USD}$. Comparing these numbers, we see that $\boxed{\text{Navin}}$ has the highest per-hour wages, and therefore would earn the most in eight hours.
 *)

theorem
fixes navin_hourly :: real
and luka_hourly :: real
and ian_hourly :: real
and navin_daily :: real
and luka_daily :: real
and ian_daily :: real
and usd_to_rupee :: real
and usd_to_kuna :: real
and usd_to_pula :: real
assumes h0 : "navin_hourly = 160 / usd_to_rupee"
and h1 : "luka_hourly = 25 / usd_to_kuna"
and h2 : "ian_hourly = 34 / usd_to_pula"
and h3 : "navin_daily = 8 * navin_hourly"
and h4 : "luka_daily = 8 * luka_hourly"
and h5 : "ian_daily = 8 * ian_hourly"
shows  "navin_daily > luka_daily \<and> navin_daily > ian_daily"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Navin earns 160 rupees per hour, Luka earns 25 kuna per hour, and Ian earns 34 pula per hour. If each of them works 8 hours a day, does Navin earn more per day than Luka and Ian?

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes navin_salary luka_salary ian_salary :: real
assumes h0 : "navin_salary = 160 / 32.35 * 8"
and h1 : "luka_salary = 25 / 5.18 * 8"
and h2 : "ian_salary = 34 / 6.95 * 8"
shows  "navin_salary > luka_salary \<and> navin_salary > ian_salary"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Navin from Mauritius, Luka from Croatia, and Ian from Botswana are chatting in the lobby of a youth hostel discussing their part-time jobs. They learn that Navin makes 160 rupee per hour, Luka makes 25 kuna per hour, and Ian makes 34 pula per hour. If one US dollar is equivalent to 32.35 Mauritius rupee, 5.18 Croatian kuna, and 6.95 Botswana pula, who would earn the most after working an eight-hour day? The final Answer is \text{Navin}
 ### Proof
 The easiest way to solve this problem is to convert the wages to US dollars and to ignore the eight-hour day. In one hour Navin makes $160\text{ rupee} \times \frac{1\text{ USD}}{32.35\text{ rupee}}\approx 4.95\; \text{USD}$.
 Luka makes $25 \text{ kuna} \times \frac{1\text{ USD}}{5.18 \text{ kuna}}\approx 4.83 \text{ USD}$. Ian makes $34\text{ pula} \times\frac{1\text{ USD}}{6.95 \text{ pula}}\approx 4.89 \text{ USD}$. Comparing these numbers, we see that $\boxed{\text{Navin}}$ has the highest per-hour wages, and therefore would earn the most in eight hours.
 *)

theorem
fixes navin_salary luka_salary ian_salary :: real
assumes h0 : "navin_salary = 160 / 32.35 * 8"
and h1 : "luka_salary = 25 / 5.18 * 8"
and h2 : "ian_salary = 34 / 6.95 * 8"
shows  "navin_salary > luka_salary \<and> navin_salary > ian_salary"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Navin's hourly wage is $160 for 32.35 hours, Luka's hourly wage is $25 for 5.18 hours, and Ian's hourly wage is $34 for 6.95 hours. Who earns the highest hourly wage? The answer is Navin.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes rupee_per_hour kuna_per_hour pula_per_hour :: real
and rupee_to_dollar kuna_to_dollar pula_to_dollar :: real
and hours :: real 
assumes h0 : "rupee_per_hour = 160"
and h1 : "kuna_per_hour = 25"
and h2 : "pula_per_hour = 34"
and h3 : "rupee_to_dollar = 32.35"
and h4 : "kuna_to_dollar = 5.18"
and h5 : "pula_to_dollar = 6.95"
and h6 : "hours = 8"
shows  "(rupee_per_hour / rupee_to_dollar) * hours > (kuna_per_hour / kuna_to_dollar) * hours"
and "(rupee_per_hour / rupee_to_dollar) * hours > (pula_per_hour / pula_to_dollar) * hours"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Navin from Mauritius, Luka from Croatia, and Ian from Botswana are chatting in the lobby of a youth hostel discussing their part-time jobs. They learn that Navin makes 160 rupee per hour, Luka makes 25 kuna per hour, and Ian makes 34 pula per hour. If one US dollar is equivalent to 32.35 Mauritius rupee, 5.18 Croatian kuna, and 6.95 Botswana pula, who would earn the most after working an eight-hour day? The final Answer is \text{Navin}
 ### Proof
 The easiest way to solve this problem is to convert the wages to US dollars and to ignore the eight-hour day. In one hour Navin makes $160\text{ rupee} \times \frac{1\text{ USD}}{32.35\text{ rupee}}\approx 4.95\; \text{USD}$.
 Luka makes $25 \text{ kuna} \times \frac{1\text{ USD}}{5.18 \text{ kuna}}\approx 4.83 \text{ USD}$. Ian makes $34\text{ pula} \times\frac{1\text{ USD}}{6.95 \text{ pula}}\approx 4.89 \text{ USD}$. Comparing these numbers, we see that $\boxed{\text{Navin}}$ has the highest per-hour wages, and therefore would earn the most in eight hours.
 *)

theorem 
fixes rupee_per_hour kuna_per_hour pula_per_hour :: real
and rupee_to_dollar kuna_to_dollar pula_to_dollar :: real
and hours :: real 
assumes h0 : "rupee_per_hour = 160"
and h1 : "kuna_per_hour = 25"
and h2 : "pula_per_hour = 34"
and h3 : "rupee_to_dollar = 32.35"
and h4 : "kuna_to_dollar = 5.18"
and h5 : "pula_to_dollar = 6.95"
and h6 : "hours = 8"
shows  "(rupee_per_hour / rupee_to_dollar) * hours > (kuna_per_hour / kuna_to_dollar) * hours"
and "(rupee_per_hour / rupee_to_dollar) * hours > (pula_per_hour / pula_to_dollar) * hours"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: You are working for 8 hours and you are paid in three different currencies: Rupees, Kuna, and Pula. If you are paid 160 rupees per hour, 25 kuna per hour, and 34 pula per hour, and the exchange rates are 32.35 rupees to the dollar, 5.18 kuna to the dollar, and 6.95 pula to the dollar, which currency would yield the highest dollar amount for your work? The final answer is Rupees.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes Navin Luka Ian :: real
and Rupee_per_hour Kuna_per_hour Pula_per_hour :: real
and USdollar_to_Rupee USdollar_to_Kuna USdollar_to_Pula :: real
and hours :: real
assumes h0 : "Rupee_per_hour = 160"
and h1 : "Kuna_per_hour = 25"
and h2 : "Pula_per_hour = 34"
and h3 : "USdollar_to_Rupee = 32.35"
and h4 : "USdollar_to_Kuna = 5.18"
and h5 : "USdollar_to_Pula = 6.95"
and h6 : "hours = 8"
and h7 : "Navin = hours * Rupee_per_hour / USdollar_to_Rupee"
and h8 : "Luka = hours * Kuna_per_hour / USdollar_to_Kuna"
and h9 : "Ian = hours * Pula_per_hour / USdollar_to_Pula"
shows  "Navin > Luka \<and> Navin > Ian"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Navin from Mauritius, Luka from Croatia, and Ian from Botswana are chatting in the lobby of a youth hostel discussing their part-time jobs. They learn that Navin makes 160 rupee per hour, Luka makes 25 kuna per hour, and Ian makes 34 pula per hour. If one US dollar is equivalent to 32.35 Mauritius rupee, 5.18 Croatian kuna, and 6.95 Botswana pula, who would earn the most after working an eight-hour day? The final Answer is \text{Navin}
 ### Proof
 The easiest way to solve this problem is to convert the wages to US dollars and to ignore the eight-hour day. In one hour Navin makes $160\text{ rupee} \times \frac{1\text{ USD}}{32.35\text{ rupee}}\approx 4.95\; \text{USD}$.
 Luka makes $25 \text{ kuna} \times \frac{1\text{ USD}}{5.18 \text{ kuna}}\approx 4.83 \text{ USD}$. Ian makes $34\text{ pula} \times\frac{1\text{ USD}}{6.95 \text{ pula}}\approx 4.89 \text{ USD}$. Comparing these numbers, we see that $\boxed{\text{Navin}}$ has the highest per-hour wages, and therefore would earn the most in eight hours.
 *)

theorem
fixes Navin Luka Ian :: real
and Rupee_per_hour Kuna_per_hour Pula_per_hour :: real
and USdollar_to_Rupee USdollar_to_Kuna USdollar_to_Pula :: real
and hours :: real
assumes h0 : "Rupee_per_hour = 160"
and h1 : "Kuna_per_hour = 25"
and h2 : "Pula_per_hour = 34"
and h3 : "USdollar_to_Rupee = 32.35"
and h4 : "USdollar_to_Kuna = 5.18"
and h5 : "USdollar_to_Pula = 6.95"
and h6 : "hours = 8"
and h7 : "Navin = hours * Rupee_per_hour / USdollar_to_Rupee"
and h8 : "Luka = hours * Kuna_per_hour / USdollar_to_Kuna"
and h9 : "Ian = hours * Pula_per_hour / USdollar_to_Pula"
shows  "Navin > Luka \<and> Navin > Ian"

 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Navin, Luka and Ian are working for 8 hours. Navin is earning 160 rupees per hour, Luka is earning 25 kunas per hour and Ian is earning 34 pula per hour. The exchange rates are 32.35 rupees per US dollar, 5.18 kuna per US dollar and 6.95 pula per US dollar. Who is earning the most in US dollars? The final answer is Navin.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes rupee kuna pula :: real
and rupee_to_usd kuna_to_usd pula_to_usd :: real
and navin_salary luka_salary ian_salary :: real
assumes h0 : "rupee_to_usd = 32.35"
and h1 : "kuna_to_usd = 5.18"
and h2 : "pula_to_usd = 6.95"
and h3 : "navin_salary = 160 / rupee_to_usd * 8"
and h4 : "luka_salary = 25 / kuna_to_usd * 8"
and h5 : "ian_salary = 34 / pula_to_usd * 8"
shows  "navin_salary > luka_salary \<and> navin_salary > ian_salary"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Navin from Mauritius, Luka from Croatia, and Ian from Botswana are chatting in the lobby of a youth hostel discussing their part-time jobs. They learn that Navin makes 160 rupee per hour, Luka makes 25 kuna per hour, and Ian makes 34 pula per hour. If one US dollar is equivalent to 32.35 Mauritius rupee, 5.18 Croatian kuna, and 6.95 Botswana pula, who would earn the most after working an eight-hour day? The final Answer is \text{Navin}
 ### Proof
 The easiest way to solve this problem is to convert the wages to US dollars and to ignore the eight-hour day. In one hour Navin makes $160\text{ rupee} \times \frac{1\text{ USD}}{32.35\text{ rupee}}\approx 4.95\; \text{USD}$.
 Luka makes $25 \text{ kuna} \times \frac{1\text{ USD}}{5.18 \text{ kuna}}\approx 4.83 \text{ USD}$. Ian makes $34\text{ pula} \times\frac{1\text{ USD}}{6.95 \text{ pula}}\approx 4.89 \text{ USD}$. Comparing these numbers, we see that $\boxed{\text{Navin}}$ has the highest per-hour wages, and therefore would earn the most in eight hours.
 *)

theorem
fixes rupee kuna pula :: real
and rupee_to_usd kuna_to_usd pula_to_usd :: real
and navin_salary luka_salary ian_salary :: real
assumes h0 : "rupee_to_usd = 32.35"
and h1 : "kuna_to_usd = 5.18"
and h2 : "pula_to_usd = 6.95"
and h3 : "navin_salary = 160 / rupee_to_usd * 8"
and h4 : "luka_salary = 25 / kuna_to_usd * 8"
and h5 : "ian_salary = 34 / pula_to_usd * 8"
shows  "navin_salary > luka_salary \<and> navin_salary > ian_salary"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem:
Navin, Luka, and Ian are all paid in different currencies: rupees, kuna, and pula respectively. The exchange rates are as follows: 1 rupee is equivalent to 32.35 USD, 1 kuna is equivalent to 5.18 USD, and 1 pula is equivalent to 6.95 USD. 

Navin makes 160 rupees per hour and works 8 hours, Luka makes 25 kuna per hour and works 8 hours, and Ian makes 34 pula per hour and also works 8 hours. 

Is Navin's salary in USD greater than both Luka's and Ian's salaries in USD?

a_7.formal problem:
datatype Worker = Navin | Luka | Ian

fun earnings :: "Worker \<Rightarrow> real"
where
"earnings Navin = 160 / 32.35 * 8" |
"earnings Luka = 25 / 5.18 * 8" |
"earnings Ian = 34 / 6.95 * 8"

theorem highest_earning_worker:
shows  "earnings Navin > earnings Luka \<and> earnings Navin > earnings Ian"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Navin from Mauritius, Luka from Croatia, and Ian from Botswana are chatting in the lobby of a youth hostel discussing their part-time jobs. They learn that Navin makes 160 rupee per hour, Luka makes 25 kuna per hour, and Ian makes 34 pula per hour. If one US dollar is equivalent to 32.35 Mauritius rupee, 5.18 Croatian kuna, and 6.95 Botswana pula, who would earn the most after working an eight-hour day? The final Answer is \text{Navin}
 ### Proof
 The easiest way to solve this problem is to convert the wages to US dollars and to ignore the eight-hour day. In one hour Navin makes $160\text{ rupee} \times \frac{1\text{ USD}}{32.35\text{ rupee}}\approx 4.95\; \text{USD}$.
 Luka makes $25 \text{ kuna} \times \frac{1\text{ USD}}{5.18 \text{ kuna}}\approx 4.83 \text{ USD}$. Ian makes $34\text{ pula} \times\frac{1\text{ USD}}{6.95 \text{ pula}}\approx 4.89 \text{ USD}$. Comparing these numbers, we see that $\boxed{\text{Navin}}$ has the highest per-hour wages, and therefore would earn the most in eight hours.
 *)

datatype Worker = Navin | Luka | Ian

fun earnings :: "Worker \<Rightarrow> real"
where
"earnings Navin = 160 / 32.35 * 8" |
"earnings Luka = 25 / 5.18 * 8" |
"earnings Ian = 34 / 6.95 * 8"

theorem highest_earning_worker:
shows  "earnings Navin > earnings Luka \<and> earnings Navin > earnings Ian"

 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Navin earns at a rate of 160 per 32.35 hours, Luka earns at a rate of 25 per 5.18 hours, and Ian earns at a rate of 34 per 6.95 hours. All earnings are calculated for 8 hours. Who earns the most? The answer is Navin.

a_8.formal problem:
datatype Country = Mauritius | Croatia | Botswana

record Job =
  country :: Country
  wage :: real

definition Navin :: Job where
"Navin = \<lparr> country = Mauritius, wage = 160/32.35 \<rparr>"

definition Luka :: Job where
"Luka = \<lparr> country = Croatia, wage = 25/5.18 \<rparr>"

definition Ian :: Job where
"Ian = \<lparr> country = Botswana, wage = 34/6.95 \<rparr>"

definition earn :: "Job \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real" where
"earn j h = wage j * h"

theorem
assumes h0 : "earn Navin 8 \<ge> earn Luka 8"
and h1 : "earn Navin 8 \<ge> earn Ian 8"
shows  "Navin earns the most after working an eight-hour day"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Navin from Mauritius, Luka from Croatia, and Ian from Botswana are chatting in the lobby of a youth hostel discussing their part-time jobs. They learn that Navin makes 160 rupee per hour, Luka makes 25 kuna per hour, and Ian makes 34 pula per hour. If one US dollar is equivalent to 32.35 Mauritius rupee, 5.18 Croatian kuna, and 6.95 Botswana pula, who would earn the most after working an eight-hour day? The final Answer is \text{Navin}
 ### Proof
 The easiest way to solve this problem is to convert the wages to US dollars and to ignore the eight-hour day. In one hour Navin makes $160\text{ rupee} \times \frac{1\text{ USD}}{32.35\text{ rupee}}\approx 4.95\; \text{USD}$.
 Luka makes $25 \text{ kuna} \times \frac{1\text{ USD}}{5.18 \text{ kuna}}\approx 4.83 \text{ USD}$. Ian makes $34\text{ pula} \times\frac{1\text{ USD}}{6.95 \text{ pula}}\approx 4.89 \text{ USD}$. Comparing these numbers, we see that $\boxed{\text{Navin}}$ has the highest per-hour wages, and therefore would earn the most in eight hours.
 *)

datatype Country = Mauritius | Croatia | Botswana

record Job =
  country :: Country
  wage :: real

definition Navin :: Job where
"Navin = \<lparr> country = Mauritius, wage = 160/32.35 \<rparr>"

definition Luka :: Job where
"Luka = \<lparr> country = Croatia, wage = 25/5.18 \<rparr>"

definition Ian :: Job where
"Ian = \<lparr> country = Botswana, wage = 34/6.95 \<rparr>"

definition earn :: "Job \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real" where
"earn j h = wage j * h"

theorem
assumes h0 : "earn Navin 8 \<ge> earn Luka 8"
and h1 : "earn Navin 8 \<ge> earn Ian 8"
shows  "Navin earns the most after working an eight-hour day"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Navin from Mauritius earns 160 Mauritian Rupees per US Dollar, Luka from Croatia earns 25 Croatian Kuna per US Dollar, and Ian from Botswana earns 34 Pula per US Dollar. If each of them works for 8 hours, who earns the most? The final answer is Navin.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes usd_rupee usd_kuna usd_pula :: real
and navin_hourly luka_hourly ian_hourly :: real
and navin_daily luka_daily ian_daily :: real
assumes h0 : "usd_rupee = 32.35"
and h1 : "usd_kuna = 5.18"
and h2 : "usd_pula = 6.95"
and h3 : "navin_hourly = 160 / usd_rupee"
and h4 : "luka_hourly = 25 / usd_kuna"
and h5 : "ian_hourly = 34 / usd_pula"
and h6 : "navin_daily = 8 * navin_hourly"
and h7 : "luka_daily = 8 * luka_hourly"
and h8 : "ian_daily = 8 * ian_hourly"
shows  "navin_daily > luka_daily \<and> navin_daily > ian_daily"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Navin from Mauritius, Luka from Croatia, and Ian from Botswana are chatting in the lobby of a youth hostel discussing their part-time jobs. They learn that Navin makes 160 rupee per hour, Luka makes 25 kuna per hour, and Ian makes 34 pula per hour. If one US dollar is equivalent to 32.35 Mauritius rupee, 5.18 Croatian kuna, and 6.95 Botswana pula, who would earn the most after working an eight-hour day? The final Answer is \text{Navin}
 ### Proof
 The easiest way to solve this problem is to convert the wages to US dollars and to ignore the eight-hour day. In one hour Navin makes $160\text{ rupee} \times \frac{1\text{ USD}}{32.35\text{ rupee}}\approx 4.95\; \text{USD}$.
 Luka makes $25 \text{ kuna} \times \frac{1\text{ USD}}{5.18 \text{ kuna}}\approx 4.83 \text{ USD}$. Ian makes $34\text{ pula} \times\frac{1\text{ USD}}{6.95 \text{ pula}}\approx 4.89 \text{ USD}$. Comparing these numbers, we see that $\boxed{\text{Navin}}$ has the highest per-hour wages, and therefore would earn the most in eight hours.
 *)

theorem
fixes usd_rupee usd_kuna usd_pula :: real
and navin_hourly luka_hourly ian_hourly :: real
and navin_daily luka_daily ian_daily :: real
assumes h0 : "usd_rupee = 32.35"
and h1 : "usd_kuna = 5.18"
and h2 : "usd_pula = 6.95"
and h3 : "navin_hourly = 160 / usd_rupee"
and h4 : "luka_hourly = 25 / usd_kuna"
and h5 : "ian_hourly = 34 / usd_pula"
and h6 : "navin_daily = 8 * navin_hourly"
and h7 : "luka_daily = 8 * luka_hourly"
and h8 : "ian_daily = 8 * ian_hourly"
shows  "navin_daily > luka_daily \<and> navin_daily > ian_daily"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: "Navin in India earns 160 rupees per hour, Luka in Croatia earns 25 kuna per hour, and Ian in Botswana earns 34 pula per hour. The conversion rates are as follows: 1 USD is equal to 32.35 rupees, 5.18 kuna, and 6.95 pula respectively. All of them work for 8 hours a day. Does Navin earn more per day compared to both Luka and Ian when their earnings are converted to USD?"
